factoid: The old prince shouted "Scoundrels! Blackguards!".
The old prince turned his face away from Princess Mary.
The old prince said "Destroying the army, destroying the men!".
The old prince asked why.
The old prince told someone to go and tell Lise.
Princess Mary sank helplessly into an armchair beside her father and wept.
Princess Mary saw Prince Andrew as he had been when he took leave of Princess Mary and Lise.
Princess Mary saw Prince Andrew's look as tender yet proud.
Princess Mary saw Prince Andrew tender and amused when he put on the little icon.
Princess Mary wondered if Prince Andrew believed.
Princess Mary wondered if Prince Andrew had repented of his unbelief.
Princess Mary wondered if Prince Andrew was now in the realms of eternal peace and blessedness.
Princess Mary asked her father how it happened.
The old prince told Princess Mary to go and tell Lise and that he would follow.
The old prince said "Go! Go! Killed in battle, where the best of Russian men and Russia’s glory were led to destruction."
The old prince said "Go, Princess Mary. Go and tell Lise. I will follow."
Princess Mary returned from her father and sat working and looked up with a curious expression of inner, happy calm peculiar to pregnant women.
Princess Mary's eyes looked within herself at something joyful and mysterious taking place within her.
Princess Mary said to Lise, "Mary, give me your hand."
Princess Mary took Lise's hand and held it below her waist.
Princess Mary's eyes were smiling expectantly.
Princess Mary's downy lip rose and remained lifted in childlike happiness.
Princess Mary knelt down before Lise and hid her face in the folds of Lise's dress.
Lise said, "There, there! Do you feel it? I feel so strange. And do you know, Mary, I am going to love him very much."
Princess Mary could not lift her head and was weeping.
Princess Mary asked, "What is the matter, Mary?"
Princess Mary said, "Nothing... only I feel sad... sad about Andrew."
Princess Mary wiped away her tears on Lise's knee.
Several times in the morning Princess Mary began trying to prepare Lise and every time began to cry.
Princess Mary was unobservant and her tears agitated her.
Princess Mary looked around uneasily.
Before dinner the old prince, whom Princess Mary was always afraid of, came into her room with a peculiar restless and malign expression and left without saying a word.
Princess Mary sat thinking for a while with an expression of attention to something within her that is only seen in pregnant women and suddenly began to cry.
Princess Mary asked, "Has anything come from Andrew?"
The old prince said, "No, you know it’s too soon for news. But my father is anxious and I feel afraid."
Princess Mary said, "So there’s nothing?"
The old prince answered, "Nothing."
Princess Mary looked firmly with her radiant eyes at Lise.
Princess Mary had determined not to tell Lise and persuaded her father to hide the terrible news from her until after her confinement, which was expected within a few days.
Princess Mary and the old prince each bore and hid their grief in their own way.
The old prince made up his mind that Prince Andrew had been killed.
The old prince sent an official to Austria to seek traces of Prince Andrew.
The old prince ordered a monument from Moscow to erect in his own garden to Prince Andrew's memory.
The old prince told everybody that Prince Andrew had been killed.
The old prince tried not to change his former way of life, but his strength failed him.
The old prince walked less, ate less, slept less, and became weaker every day.
Princess Mary hoped.
Princess Mary prayed for Prince Andrew as living and was always awaiting news of his return.
The little princess after breakfast on the morning of the nineteenth March said, "Dearest," and her downy little lip rose from old habit.
The little princess's smile manifested sorrow in every smile, the sound of every word, and even every footstep in the house since the terrible news had come.
The little princess's smile was influenced by the general mood though without knowing its cause and reminded one of the general sorrow.
The little princess said, "Dearest, I’m afraid this morning’s fruschtique—as Fóka the cook calls it—has disagreed with me."
